Legend of the 5 rings does this well, at least the 4th ed I played. And it was easy to tweak to the feeling from gritty to brutal to cinematic.
Basically you have 4 elemental 'rings' each with 2 attributes (plus the Void ring that has no associated stats and is a bit like Edge, luck, and limits the amount you can augment your various rolls). Your Health as 5 stages, each stage with a number of points equal to your earth ring x2. If you take enough damage points to get to the final stage, you're dead. Damage along the way just applies penalties. So with an earth ring of 2 your health would look like:
Dead: 4
Down: 4
Crippled: 4
Injured: 4
Hurt: 4
Grazed: 4
Nicked: 4
Healthy: 4
Effectively, your total health here would be 32
An average sword swing would be something like rolling 5d10 then picking the highest 2, with 10's exploding (roll 5, keep 2, 5k2), so you could quite easily take out half someone's health in one attack, and after a few rank-ups combat focused characters will usually be putting out 2 attacks probably looking like 8k3+2 damage and such.

There are two definitions, the modern pop culture one being an undead spellcaster who has undergone a vile ritual of undeath, who has placed their soul inside a magical container to power their eternal unlife. Its the basic definition, from their creation in D&D as a monster. The second is the Old English definition which is still present in many places in England, being a word for a corpse. This is why the lichgate on a church's property exists, its the gate through which a dead body must pass into the cemetery.
